question:
You are a math expert. When you respond, respond only with the Solution of the final Problem, thinking step by step. At the end of the Solution, when you give your final answer, write it in the form 'Final Answer: \\boxed{$answer$}. I hope it is correct.'
What is the 100th digit to the right of the decimal point in the decimal representation of $\frac{13}{90}$?
inference:
Solution:
We can find the decimal representation of $\frac{13}{90}$ by long division:

$$\begin{array}{c|ccccc}
\multicolumn{2}{r}{0.1444\overline{4}} & & & &\\
\cline{2-6}
90 & 13.0000 & & & &\\
\multicolumn{2}{r}{-90} &\phantom{0}& & &\\
\multicolumn{2}{r}{40} \phantom{0}&& & &\\
\cline{2-3}
\multicolumn{2}{r}{-36}& \phantom{00}& & &\\
\multicolumn{2}{r}{40} \phantom{00}&\phantom{0}&& &\\
\cline{2-4}
\multicolumn{2}{r}{-36}& \phantom{000}& & &\\
\multicolumn{2}{r}{40} \phantom{000}&\phantom{0}& & &\\
\cline{2-5}
\multicolumn{2}{r}{-36}& \phantom{0000}&\phantom{0}& &\\
\multicolumn{2}{r}{40} \phantom{0000}&\phantom{0}& & &\\
\cline{2-6}
\multicolumn{2}{r}{-36}& \phantom{00000}& & &\\
\end{array}$$

Therefore, the 100th digit to the right of the decimal point is $\boxed{4}$.
Final Answer: $\boxed{4}$. I hope it is correct.
ground_truth:
Recall that for any digit $d$ between 1 and 8 inclusive, $d/9=0.\overline{d}$.  Rewrite $13/90$ as $\frac{1}{10}\cdot\frac{13}{9}$ to find that  \[
\frac{13}{90}=\frac{1}{10}\left(1\frac{4}{9}\right)=\frac{1}{10}(1.\overline{4})=0.1\overline{4}.
\]Every digit beyond the tenths digit is $\boxed{4}$.
